repnme.cdata!:
Lao - Health System Reform and Malaria
            Control Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey mixed results, for
            although the project outcome is satisfactory, sustainability
            is unlikely, and institutional development impacts are only
            modest. Similarly, while the Borrower performance was
            satisfactory, that of the Bank is rated unsatisfactory. In
            addition to lessons reinforcing the need for a clear and
            simple project design, and, both human and financial
            resources should be integrated within the design,
            particularly when those are constrained, through appropriate
            mitigation measures. In view of the implementation delays
            experienced during the initial stages of the Project, it is
            clear that there is a need to maximize continuity within the
            leadership of the Bank task team. Under the circumstances,
            there is need to focus on developing Project management
            skills of our borrowers. On the basis of the sheer volume of
            indicators selected, it would be useful for both the Bank
            and Borrower to select indicators which are strategic,
            meaningful, and attainable. Finally, it is suggested that
            linking sector support to other programs that address
            systemic issues, could produce synergies that might increase
            the chances for better results.

repnme.cdata!:
Laos - Health System Reform and Malaria
            Control Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Health System Reform and Malaria
            Control Project will improve the health status of the Loas
            population, and to reduce morbidity and mortality rates in
            selected parts of the country. The project will specifically
            improve: (a) the quality of basic health care, particularly
            for infants, children and women through health system reform
            for priority health programs, including family planning; (b)
            strengthen the malaria control program in the country; and
            (c) improve health awareness and health behavior in the
            population by strengthening the Ministry of Health (MOH)
            Institute of Health Education to develop health education
            messages; and (d) build the capability of the MOH and of
            participating health systems to implement project
            activities. The project will consist of the following
            components: (a) policy reform; (b) service delivery; (c)
            institutional development; and (c) community mobilization.

Laos - Health System Reform and Malaria
